page.title: 01WOOLAVINGTON AND ENVIRONS
page.content: The area is dominated by the south Downs. The steep northern slopes drop down to lands which once formed the medieval manor of Woolavington, mentioned in the Domesday Book. The greater part of the manor became Lavington Park. In the nineteenth century this was the estate of Samuel Wilberforce, Bishop of Winchester, and it is now Seaford College, an independent school. Lavington Park runs between the villages of Duncton and Graffham; at the west gate stands Graffham Church. Next to Seaford College is Lavington Stud Farm. At the top of Duncton Hill, which carries the road from Petworth to Chichester, there is a lime quarry. Beyond that to the west are high grasslands and woodlands, dotted with occasional small farms. The South Downs Way crosses the road near Littleton Farm.
